title: Daniel Levy admits Mauricio Pochettino has players in his squad he wanted to sell in the summer
text:
Tottenham chairman Daniel Levy has admitted that things did not go according to plan for the club in the summer transfer window.

Levy as well as other members of the Executive board and senior club staff held a meeting with the Tottenham Hotspur Supporters’ Trust board at Lilywhite House last week.

In it, Levy revealed that the club had tried and failed to sell players before the closure of the window.

Daniel Levy has admitted that things did not go quite according to plan in the summer

Last week, members of the Trust Board met with representatives of the @SpursOfficial Executive Board and senior Club staff for a scheduled 'Board to Board' meeting, The report of this meeting, signed off by both the Trust and the Club, is now available 👉https://t.co/DVACrpfc4E — THST (@THSTOfficial) October 14, 2019

He continued to say that in 90 per cent of instances either a buyer could not be found for a player or the player did not wish to join the club that had expressed an interest in buying them.

This ultimately meant that the club was not able to make as many changes as desired.

The 57-year-old also reiterated just how difficult it is to get a transfer over the line, with so many moving parts. However, he insisted the the next step in the project was already underway with the signings that were made and the sale of some fringe players.

Levy revealed that manager Mauricio Pochettino has players in his squad he wanted to sell

Concerning the situations of other player contracts, Levy explained that it wasn’t possible to make a anyone sign a contract if they didn’t want to.

The Spurs chairman reminded those present that some players have been at Spurs for a long time and wanted to pursue new opportunities elsewhere.

The players want new challenges, it wasn't simply a case about not wanting to play for Tottenham any more.
description: Levy as well as other members of the Executive Board and senior club staff held a meeting with the Tottenham Hotspur Supporters' Trust Board at Lilywhite House on Tuesday.
